economist at High Frequency Economics.
It's not so much that this number is particularly bad.
It was a little bit worse than expected.
The problem is that there was a little bit worse than expected number last month as well and although two numbers don't make a trend, they do make people nervous.
The report sent stocks falling in both the United States and Europe.
By the middle of the afternoon the Dow Jones Industrial Average was down almost two percent and the NASDAQ composite index hit a six month low.
Bond prices also took a nosedive.
Ian Shepherdson says the response may have been an overreaction.
Much of the increase was in housing costs, specifically in rents.
Nigel Gault, U.S.

economist at Global Insight says that as interest rates have risen, people have stopped buying homes as fast as they were and so some people are moving into the rental market, which is already extremely tight.
It's very strange that one of the things that's happening here in core inflation is actually a reflection of a perspective weakening in housing activity, which you would expect to be disinflationary.
Gault says the question now is whether inflation has reached a point at which companies will begin passing on price increases to the public, something they've largely refrained from doing so far.
Shouldn't panic at this point.
I mean, these inflation numbers are still historically relatively low.
The unfortunate thing at the moment is things are pointing upwards, so the indication is that maybe things are going to get a bit worse before they get better.
If inflation is picking up that would force the hand of the Federal Reserve.
The Fed has already raised rates by four full percentage points over the past few years and Fed chairman Ben Bernanke warned last week that rates may have to keep rising to control inflation.
Investors are worried that today's numbers make that kind of prospect more likely.

Dozens of countries around the world have offered to send help to the United States in the wake of Hurricane Katrina, but in Europe, sympathy for the victims has mixed with criticism of America and the Bush administration.
Jerome Socolovsky reports from Madrid.
JEROME SOCOLOVSKY reporting:

Since Hurricane Katrina devastated the Gulf Coast, Europeans have been as shocked as Americans at what they saw afterward, but for many Europeans, it only confirmed what they believed all along, that Washington's priorities are all wrong.
Nicholas Franco(ph), a physicist, sits at a table outside Cafe Komatsial(ph), one of Madrid's classic watering holes.
He's not happy that the Spanish government has offered to send oil and food to America.
(Foreign language spoken)
`It's OK to send aid and show solidarity,' he says.
`The problem is that, first, the Americans should help themselves by focusing a bit more on social policy instead of investing so much in building up their military.
He believes European countries would have handled the disaster better because, he says, `social inequality is not as great here.
Olivier Farvaq(ph), a software marketer from France, sits at a nearby table.
What is very good, I think, is that for the first time US is asking for help, and the Europeans and all the countries proposed to help them.
So they know that position that they never knew before.
Around Europe, editorial writers have been having a field day.
An underlying sentiment was expressed by Le Progres of Lyon, France.
`Katrina has shown that the emperor has no clothes.
The world's superpower is powerless when confronted with nature's fury,' the paper said.
Michael Jarlner is foreign editor for the Danish newspaper Politiken.
You're not expecting from a superpower that everything's ending up in chaos and leaving the poor people behind.
You would never expect that.
I mean, so many times you have heard the word `USA and Third World' in the same line nowadays.
Glimpses of the mayhem have dominated Europe's front pages and TV news shows.
(Soundbite of German broadcast)
And I'm Melissa Block.
Former Senate Majority Leader Tom Daschle is meeting with his old colleagues at the Senate Finance Committee this afternoon, but this is no social call.
President Obama's choice to head the vast Department of Health and Human Services is going behind closed doors to go over discrepancies in his financial records.
The panel wants to know about the more than $140,000 in delinquent taxes.
The White House is standing behind its embattled nominee.
Here's White House press secretary Robert Gibbs at today's briefing.
I think the Senate will lay a serious, but corrected, mistake against that three-decade career in public service.

And in the end, the Finance Committee in the Senate, as a whole, will vote to extend his career in public service - so that he can take on the very important task of America: To reform that health-care system, and cut our costs.
NPR's Julie Rovner is following the story.
And, Julie, this story broke Friday night.
What do you lay out - exactly, what Senator Daschle's tax problems are?
Well, the Finance Committee has been looking at the last three years of former Senator Daschle's tax returns - 2005 through 2007.
Remember, he was in the Senate for 2004.
They found three main problems, and two of them are relatively minor.
Over those three years, he and his wife took deductions for more than $275,000 in charitable contributions.
It turns out, they lack the proper documentation for about $15,000 worth of those contributions.
So, they paid back about $5,600 of those deductions, plus interest.
The second one is that one of Daschle's consulting client, called Intermedia Partners, mistakenly failed to report a payment that it made to Daschle on his year-end tax form.
That resulted in a late payment of $32,000 in back taxes and interest.

The most problematic issue, though - and the one that we've been hearing the most about - is, clearly, this car and driver that the head of Intermedia Partners made available to Daschle in Washington.
Now, Daschle says it wasn't part of his compensation deal - it was more of a favor from a friend who owns the firm.
But last summer, it occurred to Daschle to ask his accountant if he should pay tax on it.
The accountant said yes, and the amount of taxes that he owed over those three years was an eye-popping $102,000.
Well, he's now paid all of this money back.
But clearly, the story is not ending there.
No - and, partly, because the numbers are just so enormous: We're talking four times more in back taxes than the new Treasure secretary, Tim Geithner, neglected to pay.

And there's also, I think, the issue of just how much money Daschle was making - something in the neighborhood of $5 million since he left the Senate, including more than $200,000 from the health interests that he will be regulating as the secretary of Health and Human Services.
President Obama says he is absolutely standing behind his nominee.
What's the status of his nomination?
Do you think it's in trouble?
I really don't think so.
I mean, first of all, he's a member of the Senate club.
It takes a lot for them to turn on one of their own.
He was a member of the Finance Committee that's going to vote on his nomination.
Down at the other end of Pennsylvania Avenue, he was one of President Obama's earliest and closest advisers.
And, many of the officials in the West Wing are former Daschle aides, including Robert Gibbs himself, the White House press secretary.
So I don't think this is making anybody very happy.
And it's certainly providing some juicy talking points for Republicans, who, over the weekend, were talking about limousine liberals who didn't pay taxes on their limousines.
But I think he'll probably pull through it.
Okay, Julie.
Thanks very much.
You're very welcome.
NPR's Julie Rovner covers health care.
Every year, tens of thousands of teenagers from around the world come to the United States to live and to learn.
Many go away with a positive experience and a positive view of the United States, but this morning we'll report on some students who did not.
They were part of a program that was supposed to improve America's image abroad.
The State Department has now shut down the cultural exchange program of the company that brought the students here.
Even so, that group plans to keep bringing foreign students into the United States, as NPR's Libby Lewis reports.
LIBBY LEWIS reporting:
Jason Yu(ph) didn't want to leave South Korea to study in America at first.
His mother talked him into it.
Yeong Mekong(ph) had been a young exchange student in Japan, and it had changed her life.
Now, her decision to push her son to come to America tugs at her.
(Through translator) How could a student who is doing nothing but studying be treated so badly?
When I think about it, it makes me so angry I want to do something.
My cherished son, treated so badly.
When Jason arrived last August, he was 16.
He had a clear idea about America.
Country of freedom, country of liberty, land of opportunity.
People are willing to help.
From Korea, Jason signed up with a group called U.S.A.
- United Students Association.
It's based outside Dallas.
U.S.A.
is one of dozens of non-profit groups that work with recruiters overseas and find homes and schools here for foreign students.
Their families can pay thousands of dollars for the privilege.
The Yu's spent $20,000 for Jason's time here.

Jason Yu said he was told he was headed for a host family in Bangor, Maine.
But when he arrived, he found he didn't have a host family.
The agency was still looking for one.
They found him one ten days later.
Nevertheless, that violates a cardinal rule of the State Department's cultural exchange programs.
Stanley Colvin directs them.
First rule: you must have a host family placement before the student arrives.
Jason Yu wasn't alone.
South Korean student Jessica Cho(ph) was a U.S.A.
student last year.
She says she and dozens of students were marooned in a Dallas hotel for weeks before the group found them host families.
In her case, it was 31 days.
